Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story: I glanced at my phone as I walked into the conference room, the screen lighting up with a flurry of messages from my mother. She wanted to know if I’d eaten, how my day was going, and if I could call her before dinner. We always talked every day, and she liked to hear every detail, no matter how small. I knew she worried if I didn’t reply quickly. But today, the pharmacy had sent me to a workshop on the latest prescription guidelines—something I couldn’t afford to miss. My manager expected me to absorb every update and bring back knowledge to share with the team. As the speaker began, my phone buzzed again. I felt the weight of my mother’s expectations pressing against the professional responsibility I owed my patients and colleagues. My mind raced, torn between the comfort of my mother’s familiar questions and the urgency of staying sharp in my field. I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
